Conference of Parties Model
  • Climate Model

Climate Model

Introduction

From the introduction of [1].

Earth System Models (ESMs) are vital tools for providing insight into the drivers behind Earth’s climate system, as well as projecting impacts of future emissions. Large scale multi-model studies, such as the Coupled Model Intercomparison Projects (CMIPs), have been used in many reports to produce projections of what the future climate may look like based on a range of different concentration scenarios, with associated emission scenarios and socioeconomic narratives quantified by Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs). In addition to simulating both the past and possible future climates, these CMIPs extensively use idealised experiments to try to determine some of the key properties of the climate system, such as the equilibrium climate sensitivity (ECS), or the transient climate response to cumulative carbon emissions.

While ESMs are integral to our current understanding of how the climate system responds to GHG and aerosol emissions, and provide the most comprehensive projections of what a future world might look like, they are so computationally expensive that only a limited set of experiments are able to be run during a CMIP. This constraint on the quantity of experiments necessitates the use of simpler models to provide probabilistic assessments and explore additional experiments and scenarios.

These models, often referred to as simple climate models (SCMs), are typically designed to emulate the response of more complex models. In general, they are able to simulate the globally averaged emission wich are convert into concentration then into radiative forcing and finally into temperature response pathway, and can be tuned to emulate an individual ESM (or multi-model-mean).

In general, SCMs are considerably less complex than ESMs: while ESMs are three dimensional, gridded, and explicitly represent dynamical and physical processes, therefore outputting many hundreds of variables, SCMs tend to be globally averaged (or cover large regions), and parameterise many processes, resulting in many fewer output variables. This reduction in complexity means that SCMs are much quicker than ESMs in terms of runtime: most SCMs can run tens of thousands of years of simulation per minute on an “average” personal computer, whereas ESMs may take several hours to run a single year on hundreds of supercomputer processors; and are much smaller in terms of the number of lines of code: SCMs tend to be on the order of thousands of lines, ESMs can be up to a million lines.

1

Nicholas Leach, Stuart Jenkins, Zebedee Nicholls, Chris Smith, John Lynch, Michelle Cain, Tristram Walsh, Bill Wu, Junichi Tsutsui, and Myles Allen. FaIRv2.0.0: A generalized impulse response model for climate uncertainty and future scenario exploration. Geoscientific Model Development, 14:3007–3036, May 2021. doi:10.5194/gmd-14-3007-2021.

Constants and Parameters

Constants

models.geophysic_models.constants.ppm_co2_to_c = 2.13

Conversion ratio of ppm of co2 to Gt of carbon

models.geophysic_models.constants.ppm_co2_to_co2 = 7.8

Conversion ratio of ppm of co2 to Gt of co2

models.geophysic_models.constants.co2_to_C = 0.2727272727272727

Conversion ratio of Gt co2 into Gt of carbon equal to 12/44

models.geophysic_models.constants.CARBON_IN_CO2_EQUIVALENT_PPM_1750 = 278

Carbon Concentration in ppm at Equilibrium (i.e pre-industrial era) as CO2 equivalent

https://www.csiro.au/en/research/environmental-impacts/climate-change/state-of-the-climate/greenhouse-gases

models.geophysic_models.constants.C_1750 = 592.14

Carbon Concentration in GtC at Equilibrium (i.e pre-industrial era)

models.geophysic_models.constants.F_2XCO2 = 3.7

Forcings of equilibrium CO2 doubling (Wm-2)

References

1

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_sensitivity

Parameters

DICE approx for Non-CO2 GHGs

models.geophysic_models.SCM_parameters.FORCING_NONCO2_0 = 0.5

2020 forcings of non-CO2 GHG (Wm-2)

models.geophysic_models.SCM_parameters.FORCING_NONCO2_100 = 1.0

2100 forcings of non-CO2 GHG (Wm-2)

models.geophysic_models.SCM_parameters.F_EX

Exogeneous forcing for other greenhouse gases (per period)

models.geophysic_models.SCM_parameters.EMISSION_LAND_0 = 2.6

Carbon emissions from land 2015 (GtCO2 per year)

models.geophysic_models.SCM_parameters.DECLINE_RATE_EMISSION_LAND = 0.115

Decline rate of land emissions (per period)

models.geophysic_models.SCM_parameters.E_EX

Emission of land (per period)

Carbon Cycle Models

Carbon Modeling structure.

The base model is discrete and linear.

Linear models of carbon cycle are mostly represented as flows of carbon between \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) different boxes or reservoirs. They are modeled as a system of \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) equations as the following

\[\begin{split}C(t) &= A_C C(t-1) + d_C E(t) , \quad \forall t \in \mathbb{N} \\ C(0) &= C_0\end{split}\]

Where,

  • \(C(t)\) is the m-vector of carbon concentration in the reservoirs at time \(t\),

  • \(E(t)\) is the CO2 emissions at time \(t\),

  • \(A_C\) is the square matrix of constants that represent the carbon flux between the boxes,

  • \(d_C\) is the vector that affects the emissions to the boxes.

The number of boxes, the matrix \(A_C\) and the vector \(d_C\) differ from a model to another.

The atmospheric Carbon concentration is given by,

\[C_{AT}(t)=b_C^{\mathrm{T}} C(t), \quad \forall t \in \mathbb{N}\]

Where \(b_C\) is the vector that will represent the atmospheric component of the CO2 concentration vector \(C(t)\). In fact, \(b_C\) will be fixed as well, in each of the following models.

class models.geophysic_models.carbon_cycle_models.Linear_Carbon_Model

Structure of a Linear Carbon Model.

Methods

atmospheric_carbon(state)

Function which return the Carbon in the atmosphere in GtC from a state.

five_years_atmospheric_carbon(emission, state)

Function which return the Carbon in the atmosphere in GtC after five years for a given emission.

five_years_cycle(emission)

Function which return the Carbon state in GtC after five years for a given emission per years.

init_carbon_cycle(initial_state)

Function which initialize the Carbon Cycle from a given state.

n_years_atmospheric_carbon(n, emission, state)

Function which return the Carbon in the atmosphere in GtC after five years for a given emission.

n_years_cycle(n, emission)

Function which return the Carbon state in GtC after \(n\) years for a given emission per years.
name: str = ' '

Name of the model

timestep: int = 1

Time-step of the model

Ac: ndarray = array([1.])

Transition matrix between the differents boxes

dc: ndarray = array([1.])

Transition vector from the emission to the boxes

bc: ndarray = array([1.])

Transition vector from the boxes to the atmospheric layer

initial_state: ndarray = array([1.])

Initial content of the boxes

init_carbon_cycle(initial_state: ndarray) → None

Function which initialize the Carbon Cycle from a given state.

Parameters
initial_statenp.ndarray

Intial state of the carbon cycle.

Function which return the Carbon state in GtC after five years for a given emission per years.

Parameters
emission (np.ndarray): Emission over the five years in GtCO2/year
Returns
np.ndarray: Carbon in the boxes after 5 years GtC

class models.geophysic_models.carbon_cycle_models.Carbon_FUND

Carbon model used in the FUND IAM.

Notes

This Carbon model initialy take emission in ppm and return atmospheric CO2 in ppm. We modified it to take emission in GtCO2 and return CtC.

For initialization we use the the jupyternotebook provided by FUND avalaible at https://github.com/fund-model/MimiFUND.jl/blob/master/calibration/co2cycle/fund_co2_cycle.ipynb for the year 2020.

Methods

atmospheric_carbon(state)

Function which return the Carbon in the atmosphere in GtC from a state.

five_years_atmospheric_carbon(emission, state)

Function which return the Carbon in the atmosphere in GtC after five years for a given emission.

five_years_cycle(emission, state)

Function that calculate one cycle of carbon for a timestep of 5 years with the FUND carbon cycle with zero order hold assumption.

init_carbon_cycle(initial_state)

Function which initialize the Carbon Cycle from a given state.

Function which return the Carbon in the atmosphere in GtC after five years for a given emission.

name: str = 'FUND'

Name of the model

timestep: int = 1

Time-step of the model

Ac: ndarray = array([[1.        , 0.        , 0.        , 0.        , 0.        ],        [0.        , 0.99724897, 0.        , 0.        , 0.        ],        [0.        , 0.        , 0.98657738, 0.        , 0.        ],        [0.        , 0.        , 0.        , 0.94287314, 0.        ],        [0.        , 0.        , 0.        , 0.        , 0.60653066]])

Transition matrix between the differents boxes, by default \(\begin{bmatrix} 1. & 0. & 0. & 0. & 0.\\ 0. & 0.99724897 & 0. & 0. & 0.\\ 0. & 0. & 0.98657738 & 0. & 0.\\ 0. & 0. & 0. & 0.94287314 & 0.\\ 0. & 0. & 0. & 0. & 0.60653066\\ \end{bmatrix}\)

dc: ndarray = array([0.01666667, 0.02564103, 0.04102564, 0.03205128, 0.01282051])

Transition vector from the emission to the boxes, by default \(\begin{bmatrix} 0.13\\ 0.2\\ 0.32\\ 0.25\\ 0.1\\ \end{bmatrix} \times \frac{1}{ppm\_co2\_to\_co2}\)

bc: ndarray = array([2.13, 2.13, 2.13, 2.13, 2.13])

Transition vector from the boxes to the atmospheric layer, by default \(\begin{bmatrix}1. & 1. & 1. & 1. & 1.\\ \end{bmatrix} \times ppm\_co2\_to\_c\)

initial_state: ndarray = array([320.34,  36.96,  43.49,  15.8 ,   1.23])

Initial content of the boxes, by default \(\begin{bmatrix} 320.34\\ 36.96\\ 43.49\\ 15.80\\ 1.23\\ \end{bmatrix}\)

five_years_cycle(emission: ndarray, state: ndarray) → ndarray

Function that calculate one cycle of carbon for a timestep of 5 years with the FUND carbon cycle with zero order hold assumption.

Parameters
emission (np.ndarray): Emission over the five years in GtCO2/year
Returns
np.ndarray: Carbon in the boxes after 5 years GtC

Methods

Function which return the Carbon state in GtC after five years for a given emission per years.

Function that calculate one cycle of carbon for a timestep of 5 years with the JOOS carbon cycle with zero order hold assumption.

Function which initialize the Carbon Cycle from a given state.

name: str = 'Joos-et-al'

Name of the model

timestep: int = 1

Time-step of the model

Ac_0: ndarray = array([[1.    , 0.    , 0.    , 0.    ],        [0.    , 0.9975, 0.    , 0.    ],        [0.    , 0.    , 0.973 , 0.    ],        [0.    , 0.    , 0.    , 0.7927]])

Transition matrix between the differents boxes, by default \(\begin{bmatrix} 1. & 0. & 0. & 0.\\ 0. & 0.9975 & 0. & 0.\\ 0. & 0. & 0.973 & 0.\\ 0. & 0. & 0. & 0.7927\\ \end{bmatrix}\)

Temperature Dynamic Models

Temperature Dynamic structure.

The base model is discrete and linear.

Linear models of temperature dynamic are mostly represented as flows of temperature between \(m' \in \mathbb{N}\) different boxes. They are modelled as a system of \(m' \in \mathbb{N}\) equations as the following

\[\begin{split}\Theta(t) &= A_\Theta \Theta(t-1) + d_\Theta F(t) , \quad \forall t \in \mathbb{N} \\ \Theta(0) &= \Theta_0\end{split}\]

Where,

  • \(\Theta(t)\) is the m’-vector of Temperature in the boxes at time \(t\),

  • \(F(t)\) is the radiative forcing at time \(t\),

  • \(A_\Theta\) is the square matrix of constants that represent the temeprature flux between the boxes,

  • \(d_\Theta\) is the vector that share the radiative forcing to the boxes.

The number of boxes, the matrix \(A_\Theta\) and the vector \(d_\Theta\) differ from a model to another.

The atmospheric temperature is given by,

\[\Theta_{AT}(t)=b_\Theta^{\mathrm{T}} \Theta(t), \quad \forall t \in \mathbb{N}\]

Where \(b_\Theta\) is the vector that extract the atmospheric temperature \(\Theta_{AT}\).

class models.geophysic_models.temperature_dynamic_model.Linear_Temperature_Dynamic

Structure of a Linear Temperature Dynamic.

class models.geophysic_models.temperature_dynamic_model.Temp_Discret_Geoffroy

Temperature Dynamic from Geoffroy et al. model.

Notes

The temperature dynamic is given by the following EDO

\[\begin{split}&\dot{\Theta} = A_\Theta \Theta + d_\Theta F\\ &\Theta_{AT} = d_\Theta \Theta\end{split}\]

With the transition matrix and the vectors given by

\[\begin{split}A_\Theta = \begin{bmatrix} -(\lambda + \gamma) /C & \gamma/C \\ \gamma/C_0 & - \gamma/C_0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad d_\Theta = \begin{bmatrix} 1/C\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{ and } \quad b_\Theta = \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]

References

1

Geoffroy, O., D. Saint-Martin, D. J. L. Olivié, A. Voldoire, G. Bellon, et S. Tytéca. « Transient Climate Response in a Two-Layer Energy-Balance Model. Part I: Analytical Solution and Parameter Calibration Using CMIP5 AOGCM Experiments ». Journal of Climate 26, nᵒ 6 (15 mars 2013): 1841‑57. https://doi.org/10.1175/JCLI-D-12-00195.1.

2

Kellett, Christopher M., Steven R. Weller, Timm Faulwasser, Lars Grüne, et Willi Semmler. « Feedback, Dynamics, and Optimal Control in Climate Economics». Annual Reviews in Control 47 (1 janvier 2019): 7-20. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.arcontrol.2019.04.003.

3

Rezai, Armon, Simon Dietz, Frederick van der Ploeg, et Frank Venmans. « Are Economists Getting Climate Dynamics Right and Does It Matter? » Copernicus Meetings, 9 mars 2020. https://doi.org/10.5194/egusphere-egu2020-20039.

Simple Climate Model

The Simple Climate Model (SCM) object is composed of a Carbon Model, a Radiative Forcing Formula and a Temperature Dynamic.

The idea of the SCM is to have a object to which we can provide some CO2 emission and being able to predict a atmospheric temperature after some time.

class models.geophysic_models.climate_model.Simple_Climate_Model(carbon_model: Linear_Carbon_Model, temperature_model: Linear_Temperature_Dynamic, non_human_carbon_emission=E_EX, non_co2_radiative_forcing=F_EX)

Class joining the Carbon Cycle model, the radiative forcing and the temperature dynamic together.
